Bash(git commit -m "$(cat <<''EOF''
Initial commit: Audio Recorder Manager in Rust

This is a high-performance audio recorder built with Rust, converted from 
the original Python implementation. The recorder captures system audio using 
WASAPI loopback on Windows and supports both WAV and M4A output formats.

Features:
- WASAPI loopback recording for capturing system audio on Windows
- Real-time status updates with JSON output
- Support for WAV (16-bit PCM) and M4A (AAC) formats
- Proper handling of 32-bit float audio from Windows
- Manual recording mode with stop signals
- Professional quality audio (48kHz, stereo)

Technical improvements:
- Fixed silent audio issue by properly detecting WAVEFORMATEXTENSIBLE format
- Correct 32-bit float to 16-bit PCM conversion
- Proper handling of AUDCLNT_BUFFERFLAGS_SILENT flag
- Lock-free atomic operations for frame counting
- Native threading with async/await support

Build system:
- GNU toolchain configuration for Windows
- PowerShell and batch build scripts
- Cross-platform support (Windows primary, Linux/macOS fallback)

Bash(git commit -m "$(cat <<''EOF''
Phase 2: Implement Status Observer Pattern

Created a flexible observer pattern for status reporting that separates 
concerns and makes it easy to add new status reporters.

New modules:
- src/status/mod.rs: Status module exports
- src/status/observer.rs: StatusObserver trait and data models
- src/status/json_observer.rs: JsonFileObserver implementation

Changes:
- Refactored status writing to use observer pattern
- Removed write_wasapi_status() function
- Created RecordingStatus and RecordingResult types
- Implemented JsonFileObserver for file-based status reporting
- Updated main.rs to use observer.on_progress() and observer.on_complete()

Benefits:
- Separation of concerns: Status reporting logic isolated from recording
- Extensibility: Easy to add new observers (websockets, databases, etc.)
- Testability: Each observer can be tested independently
- Clean interfaces: Trait-based design with clear contracts

Tested:
- WAV recording with observer pattern works correctly
- Status files are written properly
- All existing functionality preserved
